title.EN: What is FERPA & Who Must Comply?
FERPA: Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act

content1.EN:
• [TERM FERPA]Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act[/TERM] is a federal act intended to protect the privacy and accuracy of student records.

  • Consider the student as the "owner" and the institution as the "custodian" of these records.

In order to conduct daily business, schools must record and maintain a great deal of information about students. With modern technologies, the potential for misuse—whether unintentional or criminal—exists as never before. It is important that educational institutions safeguard students' sensitive information.

• ANY institution receiving federal funding (e.g., Pell Grants, financial aid, loan programs)

  • EVERY department throughout the institution, not merely records offices

  • EVERYONE on campus who has access to student information

• The Department of Education's FPCO (Family Policy Compliance Office) enforces the act.

  • The FPCO issues a formal notice when a violation is reported.

[CAMPUSCLUE]If a violation occurs at your school, the FPCO allows a reasonable amount of time to correct the situation and return to compliance.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

  • Noncompliance in ANY department can mean a loss of federal funding for the ENTIRE institution!

  • Having a firm understanding of FERPA's definitions, provisions, and scope of liability will guide you in your day-to-day decisions and in extenuating circumstances.
